intro: Fraxinus purpusii, commonly known as the Japanese ash, is a deciduous tree native to Japan. It belongs to the Oleaceae family and is characterized by its compound leaves with serrated edges. The tree produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in clusters, followed by winged seeds that are dispersed by wind. It typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters and is often found in moist, well-drained soils. The bark is smooth and grayish-brown, becoming fissured with age.
